Hey John,

I know you probably get swamped with e-mails, but wanted to reach out to you with a question about your application module tips (already watched the majority of your new PluralSight video - fantastic job). This is related to the “core” module concept.

When you have modules that depend on using another module’s “Provider” in a config block - does this strategy break down a little? I think your demonstration touched on this very briefly, when you shifted your blocks modules around a bit, and you quickly explained it wouldn’t work because of some config requirements.

For instance, if you have features in separate modules, and those features each register their routes in config blocks via the $routeProvider - don’t those routes both have to define a module dependency on ‘ngRoute’ (directly or indirectly)?

I have a Plunkr of the simplest scenario of this demonstration:

http://plnkr.co/edit/aHOpWDzNp0cowaCvzXuB

My question is - it seems that the application is consistently running OK if ‘core’ is the first dependency declared… for safety, would you recommend explicitly defining ‘core’ as a module dependency for the two feature modules?

Sorry for the long-winded email.

Thanks again for all of the information you’ve shared, you’ve made me a better developer and your contributions to the community are greatly appreciated.
